description: From Middle English tutour, from Old French tuteur (French tuteur), from Latin tūtor (“a watcher, protector, guardian”), from tueor (“protect”); see tuition.

entries.meaning: One who teaches another (usually called a student, learner, or tutee) in a one-on-one or small-group interaction.
examples: He passed the difficult class with help from his tutor.

entries.meaning: (UK) A university officer responsible for students in a particular hall.
(obsolete or Quebec law) One who has the charge of a child or pupil and his estate; a guardian.

verbs.description: tutor (third-person singular simple present tutors, present participle tutoring, simple past and past participle tutored)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To instruct or teach, especially an individual or small group.
examples: To help pay her tuition, the college student began to tutor high school students in calculus and physics.

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To treat with authority or sternness.

description: Ellipsis of Demonic tutor, name of an early Magic: The Gathering card with this effect.

entries.meaning: (collectible card games) A card that allows one to search one's deck for one or more other cards.

verbs.description: tutor (third-person singular simple present tutors, present participle tutoring, simple past and past participle tutored)

entries.meaning: (collectible card games) To fetch a card from one's deck.
